text:
(1) Third Avenue, west side, north from no. 270 between 21st and 22nd Streets.
May 21, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a point slightly southward (21st Street). Note the 23rd Street station of the Third Ave. Elevated Line.
October 2, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(1) Third Avenue, west side, north from no. 270 between 21st and 22nd Streets.
May 21, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a point slightly southward (21st Street). Note the 23rd Street station of the Third Ave. Elevated Line.
October 2, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

21st Street, west from N.W. corner of Third Avenue. Gramercy Park is on the south side.
May 21, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Third Ave., east side, north from, but not including East 21st Street, showing the Third Ave. Elevated Line, and its 23rd Street station. Also seen (in the background), is the tower of the Chrysler Building. Note the Christmas trees displayed on the sidewalk.
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a point several feet southward. The restaurant shown on the extreme right, is "Beefsteak John's".
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A view of No. 265 Third Ave., adjoining the N.E. corner of East 21st Street, showing the restaurant mentioned in No. 2.
August 5, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Third Ave., east side, north from, but not including East 21st Street, showing the Third Ave. Elevated Line, and its 23rd Street station. Also seen (in the background), is the tower of the Chrysler Building. Note the Christmas trees displayed on the sidewalk.
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a point several feet southward. The restaurant shown on the extreme right, is "Beefsteak John's".
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A view of No. 265 Third Ave., adjoining the N.E. corner of East 21st Street, showing the restaurant mentioned in No. 2.
August 5, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Third Ave., east side, north from, but not including East 21st Street, showing the Third Ave. Elevated Line, and its 23rd Street station. Also seen (in the background), is the tower of the Chrysler Building. Note the Christmas trees displayed on the sidewalk.
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, from a point several feet southward. The restaurant shown on the extreme right, is "Beefsteak John's".
December 23, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A view of No. 265 Third Ave., adjoining the N.E. corner of East 21st Street, showing the restaurant mentioned in No. 2.
August 5, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
East 21st Street, at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Third Ave., showing, a row of 3-1/2 3-story buildings (Nos.157 to 149 East 21st Street and 260 Third Ave.,); 3 four story structures, )Nos.151 to 147) and 2 five story houses (Nos.145 and 143). The corner building bears only No.260 Third Ave. and appears in Bromleys R.E. Atlas (1922) as a 4-story structure. Overhead on the Ave. is the Third Ave. Elevated Line.
August 5, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A detail of same, showing the 4 and 5-story units mention in No.1. They are Nos.151 to 147 and 145 to 143 respectively. The modern apartment house appearing on the left is No.44 Gramercy Park which replaced several brownstone houses that were numbered 135 to 141 East 21st Street.
August 5, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A portion of No.1, in an eastward direction and across Third Ave., showing mainly the 3-1/2-story structures at the N.W. corner. They consist of Nos.153 to 157 East 21st Street and No.260 Third Ave; the latter being directly at the corner. Appearing across the avenue and at the N.E. corner of this street is a 4-story edifice that bears No.263 Third Ave. and No.201 East 21st Street.
August 5, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
East 21st Street, at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Third Ave., showing, a row of 3-1/2 3-story buildings (Nos.157 to 149 East 21st Street and 260 Third Ave.,); 3 four story structures, )Nos.151 to 147) and 2 five story houses (Nos.145 and 143). The corner building bears only No.260 Third Ave. and appears in Bromleys R.E. Atlas (1922) as a 4-story structure. Overhead on the Ave. is the Third Ave. Elevated Line.
August 5, 1937
P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.
